title: Deuteronomy Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 26.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:2, what shall you take from the land given by the LORD your God?
options: The first of all the fruit of the earth
The last fruits of the harvest
Only the grains and seeds
The largest animals
questions.correctAnswer: The first of all the fruit of the earth
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:2 instructs to take the first of all the fruit of the earth from the land given by God.

questions.question: Who shall you present the basket of firstfruits to according to Deuteronomy 26:3?
options: The priest
The king
The elders
The Levites
questions.correctAnswer: The priest
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:3 states you shall go to the priest and make your profession before the LORD.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:5, from where did the father of Israel come?
options: A Syrian ready to perish
Egypt
Babylon
Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: A Syrian ready to perish
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:5 describes the father as a Syrian ready to perish who went down into Egypt.

questions.question: What did the Egyptians do to Israel as stated in Deuteronomy 26:6?
options: Evil entreated and afflicted them, and laid hard bondage
Blessed them
Taught them agriculture
Made treaties with them
questions.correctAnswer: Evil entreated and afflicted them, and laid hard bondage
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:6 says the Egyptians evil entreated Israel, afflicted them, and laid hard bondage on them.

questions.question: How did the LORD bring Israel out of Egypt according to Deuteronomy 26:8?
options: With a mighty hand and outstretched arm
Silently and secretly
Through a prophet only
By sending angels alone
questions.correctAnswer: With a mighty hand and outstretched arm
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:8 states God brought them out with a mighty hand and outstretched arm, with signs and wonders.

questions.question: What kind of land did God give Israel as mentioned in Deuteronomy 26:9?
options: A land flowing with milk and honey
A desert land
A land of mountains only
A land full of rivers but no crops
questions.correctAnswer: A land flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:9 describes the land given as one that floweth with milk and honey.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:11, who shall rejoice in every good thing the LORD has given?
options: You, your household, the Levite, and the stranger
Only the Levites
Only the king and his family
The priests alone
questions.correctAnswer: You, your household, the Levite, and the stranger
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:11 instructs that you, your house, the Levite, and the stranger shall rejoice in God's good gifts.

questions.question: What must you do with all the tithes of your increase in the third year according to Deuteronomy 26:12?
options: Give them to the Levite, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow
Keep them for yourself
Use them to build altars
Sell them in the market
questions.correctAnswer: Give them to the Levite, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:12 commands giving tithes to the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow so they may be filled.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 26:13, what do you declare after giving the hallowed things to the needy?
options: I have not transgressed thy commandments, neither have I forgotten them
I have kept them for myself
I have sold them for profit
I have shared them only with family
questions.correctAnswer: I have not transgressed thy commandments, neither have I forgotten them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:13 shows the declaration of obedience and remembering God's commandments after giving the offerings.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 26:14 states that the firstfruits can be eaten in mourning.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:14 specifically says the firstfruits must not be eaten in mourning or used for unclean purposes.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 26:15 ask God to do from His holy habitation?
options: Look down and bless Israel and the land
Send a prophet
Pour out wrath
Bring a great famine
questions.correctAnswer: Look down and bless Israel and the land
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:15 requests God to look down from heaven and bless His people and the land He has given.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 26:16 commands to keep God's statutes and judgments with all your heart and soul.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:16 commands keeping statutes and judgments wholeheartedly and with all soul.

questions.question: Who has the LORD avouched this day to be His peculiar people according to Deuteronomy 26:18?
options: Israel
Egyptians
Babylonians
Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:18 says the LORD has avouched Israel to be His peculiar people as promised.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 26:19 says Israel will be made high above all nations in praise, name, and honor.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: According to Deuteronomy 26:19, God will exalt Israel above all nations in praise, name, and honor.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Deuteronomy 26:1: 'And it shall be, when thou art come in unto the land which the LORD thy God giveth thee for an ______, and possessest it, and dwellest therein;'
options: inheritance
offering
sacrifice
promise
questions.correctAnswer: inheritance
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:1 states the land given by the LORD is for an inheritance.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 teach us about gratitude toward God's provision when entering a new stage in life?
options: Bring the firstfruits of the land and present them before the LORD with rejoicing
Build a monument to celebrate personal achievements
Keep the blessings to oneself without sharing
Offer sacrifices only when feeling thankful
questions.correctAnswer: Bring the firstfruits of the land and present them before the LORD with rejoicing
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:1-11 instructs the Israelites to bring the firstfruits of the land God has given them and present them before the LORD with rejoicing, expressing gratitude for His provision and faithfulness.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overwhelmed by hardships and wonders how to respond with faith. What biblical truth from Deuteronomy 26 would you share?
options: God hears our cries and delivers us with mighty power
We must rely solely on our own strength to overcome trials
Trials mean God has forsaken us
Suffering should be hidden and not shared
questions.correctAnswer: God hears our cries and delivers us with mighty power
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:7-8 teaches that when the Israelites cried out, the LORD heard their affliction and delivered them out of Egypt with a mighty hand and wonders, encouraging trust in God's powerful deliverance.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 emphasize the importance of obedience in spiritual discipline?
options: Keep and do God's statutes wholeheartedly as commanded this day
Only obey laws that seem convenient
Obedience is optional depending on circumstances
Obedience is only for priests and leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Keep and do God's statutes wholeheartedly as commanded this day
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:16 commands believers to keep and do God's statutes and judgments with all their heart and soul, highlighting wholehearted obedience as a key spiritual discipline.

questions.question: What practical lesson about generosity and stewardship can we learn from Deuteronomy 26 regarding tithes?
options: Give tithes to the Levite, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow so they may be satisfied
Keep all increase for personal use
Give tithes only when convenient
Tithes are only for temple maintenance
questions.correctAnswer: Give tithes to the Levite, the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow so they may be satisfied
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:12-13 instructs giving all the tithes of increase in the third year to those in need, teaching generosity and caring stewardship toward others in the community.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 guide us in maintaining honesty and integrity in worship and offerings?
options: Do not eat offerings in mourning or use them for unclean purposes
Offerings can be used for any personal needs
It's acceptable to forget God's commandments in offerings
Offerings should be hidden from the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Do not eat offerings in mourning or use them for unclean purposes
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:14 emphasizes not eating offerings in mourning, nor using them for unclean purposes, reflecting integrity and respect in worship practices.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with remembering God's faithfulness. What does Deuteronomy 26 teach about recalling God's past works?
options: Declare to the priest how God brought the ancestors out of Egypt and gave the land flowing with milk and honey
Ignore past blessings and focus only on the present
Only remember personal achievements
Forget the history shared by the community
questions.correctAnswer: Declare to the priest how God brought the ancestors out of Egypt and gave the land flowing with milk and honey
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:3-10 includes a declaration to the priest recounting God's mighty acts in delivering Israel from Egypt and giving them the land, teaching the importance of remembering and confessing God's faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 encourage humility and contentment in our relationship with God?
options: Recognize that the land and blessings are gifts from God, not personal achievements
Claim all blessings as earned by personal effort
Demand more blessings without gratitude
Boast about possessions to others
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that the land and blessings are gifts from God, not personal achievements
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:10 teaches presenting firstfruits as a gift from God, acknowledging His provision and fostering humility and contentment instead of pride.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 26, the Israelites were instructed to rejoice only for their own household and exclude others.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:11 states to rejoice in all good things the LORD has given to you, your household, the Levite, and the stranger among you, promoting inclusive joy and fellowship.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 26 teaches that God avouches Israel to be His peculiar people and promises to make them high above all nations if they keep His commandments.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:18-19 confirms that God avouches Israel as His special people and promises exaltation above nations conditional on obedience to His commandments.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When presenting the firstfruits, the Israelite was to say, 'A Syrian ready to perish was my father, and he went down into Egypt, and sojourned there with a few, and became there a nation, ______, mighty, and populous.'
options: great
small
weak
unknown
questions.correctAnswer: great
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:5 states the father became a nation great, mighty, and populous, illustrating God's blessing and growth.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 teach the importance of acknowledging God's commandments in daily life?
options: Declare before God that you have not forgotten or transgressed His commandments
Ignore commandments that seem difficult
Only follow commandments when convenient
Rely on human wisdom over God's laws
questions.correctAnswer: Declare before God that you have not forgotten or transgressed His commandments
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:13 includes a confession of obedience to God's commandments, showing the importance of remembering and faithfully following His instructions.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline is illustrated by presenting a basket of firstfruits before the altar according to Deuteronomy 26?
options: Offering the first and best of what God has provided as an act of worship
Saving the best for oneself
Giving leftovers as offerings
Procrastinating worship until convenient
questions.correctAnswer: Offering the first and best of what God has provided as an act of worship
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:2-4 instructs bringing the firstfruits in a basket to the priest and altar, symbolizing giving God the first and best in worship and gratitude.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 highlight God's response when His people cry out in distress?
options: The LORD hears and looks upon their affliction and delivers them
God remains silent and distant
People must endure without help
Only priests can intercede for deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD hears and looks upon their affliction and delivers them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:7-8 explains that when Israel cried out, the LORD heard their voice, looked on their affliction, and brought them out of Egypt with mighty power.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 26 teach about the relationship between obedience and God's blessings on the land?
options: Obedience to God's statutes leads to His blessing on the land as promised
Blessings come regardless of obedience
Obedience decreases blessings
Blessings are unrelated to God's commands
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's statutes leads to His blessing on the land as promised
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:15 and 26:16 link obedience to God's commandments with receiving His blessing on Israel and the land He has given.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26, what is a key aspect of the community life we are to maintain?
options: Sharing resources with the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow to ensure they are filled
Keeping resources only within one's family
Ignoring the needs of others in the community
Prioritizing only personal wealth accumulation
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing resources with the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow to ensure they are filled
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:12 commands giving tithes to those in need so they can eat and be satisfied, emphasizing communal care and generosity.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 26.

questions.question: What is the significance of bringing the 'firstfruits of the land' in Deuteronomy 26?
options: It acknowledges God's provision and the fulfillment of His promise to the ancestors
It is a ritual to appease the gods of the land
It symbolizes the wealth of the individual
It marks the beginning of the harvest season
questions.correctAnswer: It acknowledges God's provision and the fulfillment of His promise to the ancestors
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:2-10 describes the offering of firstfruits as a declaration that God has given the land as promised to the ancestors, showing gratitude and recognition of God's providence.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is similar to the 'firstfruits' offering described in Deuteronomy 26?
options: Egyptian grain offerings to their gods
Babylonian temple tribute
Hittite vassal tribute
Canaanite harvest festival
questions.correctAnswer: Egyptian grain offerings to their gods
questions.explanation: The offering of firstfruits to God parallels ancient Egyptian practices where the first of the harvest was dedicated to deities, indicating a shared cultural practice of dedicating first yield to divine beings (Deuteronomy 26:2).

questions.question: In the declaration made by the offerer, who is described as 'a Syrian ready to perish'?
options: The offerer's father
The priest
The Levite
The stranger
questions.correctAnswer: The offerer's father
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:5 identifies the speaker's father as 'a Syrian ready to perish' who went down to Egypt and became a great nation, referencing the patriarchal origins of Israel.

questions.question: Which literary device is primarily used in the recital the offerer makes before the priest (Deuteronomy 26:5-10)?
options: Typology, foreshadowing the Exodus and covenant fulfillment
Parable, illustrating moral lessons
Hyperbole to exaggerate God's power
Allegory representing the land
questions.correctAnswer: Typology, foreshadowing the Exodus and covenant fulfillment
questions.explanation: The recital in verses 5-10 functions typologically, recounting the ancestor's migration, oppression in Egypt, divine deliverance, and gift of the land, thus foreshadowing the covenant history of Israel.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 26:12, the 'third year' is specifically called what?
options: The year of tithing
The year of jubilee
The year of release
The year of fasting
questions.correctAnswer: The year of tithing
questions.explanation: Verse 12 describes the third year as the 'year of tithing,' during which the tithes are given to the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow to ensure they are fed.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:13, what must the offerer affirm regarding the commandments?
options: That they have not transgressed or forgotten them
That they have obeyed some commandments selectively
That they have received forgiveness for transgressions
That they do not fully understand the commandments
questions.correctAnswer: That they have not transgressed or forgotten them
questions.explanation: The offerer solemnly declares in verse 13 that they have neither transgressed nor forgotten God's commandments in the process of giving the tithe.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the offerer stating, 'I have not eaten thereof in my mourning' in verse 14?
options: It emphasizes the purity and holiness of the offering
It indicates the offering is only for joyous occasions
It shows a prohibition against eating during mourning
It implies the offering is for the dead
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the purity and holiness of the offering
questions.explanation: Verse 14 stresses that the offering has not been defiled by being eaten during mourning or used for unclean purposes, underscoring the sacredness required in giving to God.

questions.question: Which phrase in Deuteronomy 26:15 is a direct petition for divine blessing that parallels other biblical covenant prayers?
options: "Look down from thy holy habitation, from heaven, and bless thy people Israel"
"I have brought the firstfruits of the land"
"Thou hast avouched the LORD this day to be thy God"
"When we cried unto the LORD God of our fathers"
questions.correctAnswer: "Look down from thy holy habitation, from heaven, and bless thy people Israel"
questions.explanation: This petition in verse 15 resembles covenant blessings found in passages like Numbers 6:24-26, requesting God's presence and favor upon Israel and the land.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 26 commands the people to keep the statutes and judgments with a divided heart.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 16 commands the people to keep and do the statutes and judgments with all their heart and soul, indicating wholehearted obedience.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 26:17 describes the people's commitment to God. Which of the following best summarizes this vow?
options: To walk in God's ways and keep His commandments
To build a temple for God
To conquer all neighboring nations
To offer sacrifices daily
questions.correctAnswer: To walk in God's ways and keep His commandments
questions.explanation: Verse 17 states the people have avouched the LORD to be their God and to walk in His ways, keeping His statutes, commandments, and judgments.

questions.question: How does the concept of being God's 'peculiar people' in verse 18 relate to other biblical themes?
options: It reflects God's special covenant relationship with Israel
It indicates Israel is to remain isolated from all nations
It suggests Israel is superior by birthright alone
It means Israel must build physical walls around their cities
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God's special covenant relationship with Israel
questions.explanation: Calling Israel God's 'peculiar people' in verse 18 echoes themes in Exodus 19:5-6 and 1 Peter 2:9, emphasizing their set-apart status and covenant identity.

questions.question: What is the intended outcome for Israel being made 'high above all nations' as stated in verse 19?
options: To be a holy people in praise, name, and honour unto the LORD
To dominate neighboring kingdoms militarily
To accumulate great wealth and possessions
To remain hidden and unknown among nations
questions.correctAnswer: To be a holy people in praise, name, and honour unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 19 explains that Israel is elevated to be holy and honored above nations to reflect God's glory, not for worldly power.

questions.question: The declaration of the offerer in verses 5-10 can be seen as a form of which biblical literary structure?
options: Covenant lawsuit (rib)
Parable
Genealogical record
Wisdom proverb
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant lawsuit (rib)
questions.explanation: The recital functions as a covenant lawsuit where Israel recounts God's faithfulness and their obedience, framing the offering as covenant renewal (Deuteronomy 26:5-10).

questions.question: How does the offering of firstfruits in Deuteronomy 26 relate typologically to New Testament teachings?
options: It foreshadows Christ as the firstfruits of resurrection
It predicts the destruction of the Temple
It symbolizes the abundance of wealth for believers
It represents the Mosaic Law as obsolete
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Christ as the firstfruits of resurrection
questions.explanation: The firstfruits offering typologically prefigures Christ's resurrection as the 'firstfruits' of those who have died (1 Corinthians 15:20), connecting Old and New Testament themes.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 26, the Levites, strangers, fatherless, and widows are recipients of the tithes in the year of tithing.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 12 clearly states that the tithes in the third year are to be given to the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow so that they may eat and be satisfied within the gates.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:1-2, what is the first act a believer must do upon entering the land given by the LORD?
options: Bring the first of all the fruit of the earth in a basket to the LORD's chosen place
Build an altar and offer burnt offerings
Gather the people and read the Law aloud
Appoint priests to administer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Bring the first of all the fruit of the earth in a basket to the LORD's chosen place
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:1-2 commands the believer to take the firstfruits of the land and bring them in a basket to the place the LORD chooses. This act symbolizes acknowledging God's provision and covenant faithfulness, as echoed in Proverbs 3:9 and 1 Corinthians 16:15.

questions.question: In the declaration before the priest, what historical reality is acknowledged about the ancestors, according to Deuteronomy 26:5?
options: A Syrian ready to perish was my father, who sojourned in Egypt and became a great nation
They were kings who ruled over many nations
They were priests and prophets in the wilderness
They dwelt peacefully in Canaan without oppression
questions.correctAnswer: A Syrian ready to perish was my father, who sojourned in Egypt and became a great nation
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:5 recalls the humble origins of Israel's ancestors, emphasizing God's providential preservation and fulfillment of promises, consistent with Acts 7:2-3 and Romans 9:17.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 26:8 emphasize about God's deliverance from Egypt?
options: It was accomplished with a mighty hand, outstretched arm, and great signs and wonders
It was a peaceful migration with no conflict
It was achieved by the people's own strength
It was done secretly without public notice
questions.correctAnswer: It was accomplished with a mighty hand, outstretched arm, and great signs and wonders
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:8 describes God's powerful intervention in delivering Israel, highlighting His sovereign power and miraculous works, aligning with Exodus 14:31, Psalm 136:12, and Hebrews 11:29.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:10, what attitude should accompany presenting the firstfruits to the LORD?
options: Worship and reverence before the LORD
Casual offering without ceremony
Offering only for personal blessing
Silence and secrecy
questions.correctAnswer: Worship and reverence before the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 26:10 instructs that the firstfruits are to be set before the LORD with worship, emphasizing gratitude and recognition of God’s sovereignty, consistent with Psalm 95:6 and John 4:23-24.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 26:11, who besides the offerer should rejoice in the good things given by the LORD?
options: The offerer, the Levite, and the stranger among you
Only the offerer and his family
The priests exclusively
No one else, it is a private celebration
questions.correctAnswer: The offerer, the Levite, and the stranger among you
questions.explanation: This verse includes the Levite and the stranger in rejoicing, illustrating God's care for all, including the marginalized, paralleling Leviticus 23:22 and Luke 14:12-14.

questions.question: What is the significance of the third-year tithe mentioned in Deuteronomy 26:12?
options: It is given to the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow so they may eat and be filled
It is saved for future harvests
It is offered as a burnt sacrifice
It is redistributed among the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: It is given to the Levite, stranger, fatherless, and widow so they may eat and be filled
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 26:12 highlights social justice and provision for vulnerable groups, reflecting God's heart for the poor, as seen in Deuteronomy 14:28-29 and James 1:27.

questions.question: What confession does the offerer make before the LORD after giving the tithes, according to Deuteronomy 26:13?
options: I have not transgressed your commandments nor forgotten them
I have earned these gifts by my own strength
I have withheld some for myself
I offer these gifts reluctantly
questions.correctAnswer: I have not transgressed your commandments nor forgotten them
questions.explanation: Verse 26:13 expresses obedience and faithfulness to God's commands, underscoring covenant faithfulness, consistent with Psalm 119:60 and 1 John 2:3-6.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 26:14, what is prohibited concerning the offerings?
options: Eating offerings in mourning, using them for unclean purposes, or giving them for the dead
Selling the offerings for profit
Offering animals instead of produce
Offering in secret without the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Eating offerings in mourning, using them for unclean purposes, or giving them for the dead
questions.explanation: Verse 26:14 forbids defiling offerings, emphasizing purity and reverence, reflecting Leviticus 22:4-7 and 2 Corinthians 6:16-18.

questions.question: What petition is made to God in Deuteronomy 26:15 after the offerings and confession?
options: Look down from heaven and bless Israel and the land as promised
Bring immediate victory over enemies
Send rain for the crops
Remove all suffering instantly
questions.correctAnswer: Look down from heaven and bless Israel and the land as promised
questions.explanation: The verse reflects trust in God's covenant faithfulness to bless the people and land, paralleling Psalm 67:1 and Jeremiah 31:12.

questions.question: What is the nature of the statutes and judgments commanded by the LORD in Deuteronomy 26:16?
options: They are to be kept with all heart and soul
They are optional guidelines
They are burdensome laws to be avoided
They only apply to priests
questions.correctAnswer: They are to be kept with all heart and soul
questions.explanation: Verse 26:16 commands wholehearted obedience, affirming covenant loyalty, consistent with Deuteronomy 6:5 and Matthew 22:37.

questions.question: What covenant relationship is affirmed in Deuteronomy 26:17 by the people with the LORD?
options: They avouch the LORD to be their God and commit to walk in His ways
They reject the LORD and follow other gods
They remain neutral in their allegiance
They choose to keep only part of the commandments
questions.correctAnswer: They avouch the LORD to be their God and commit to walk in His ways
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes the people's voluntary covenant commitment, echoing Joshua 24:15 and Romans 10:9.

questions.question: How does the LORD respond to Israel’s commitment in Deuteronomy 26:18?
options: He avouches Israel as His peculiar people and promises blessing for obedience
He rejects their commitment because of past sins
He remains silent and indifferent
He demands sacrifices without covenant promises
questions.correctAnswer: He avouches Israel as His peculiar people and promises blessing for obedience
questions.explanation: The LORD confirms His covenant relationship, declaring Israel His treasured possession, consistent with Exodus 19:5 and 1 Peter 2:9.

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose for making Israel 'high above all nations' according to Deuteronomy 26:19?
options: To be holy and praised in name and honour before the LORD
To dominate other nations militarily
To accumulate wealth and power
To isolate themselves from other peoples
questions.correctAnswer: To be holy and praised in name and honour before the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 26:19 reveals God's purpose for Israel's exaltation is holiness and glory to His name, reflected in Isaiah 43:21 and 1 Corinthians 1:2.

questions.question: What theological theme is primarily expressed in the firstfruits offering described in Deuteronomy 26?
options: Acknowledgment of God's providence and covenant faithfulness
Human merit and earning salvation
Secretive magical rituals
Exclusive priestly privileges
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledgment of God's providence and covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: The firstfruits offering symbolizes gratitude for God's provision and covenant fulfillment (Deut 26:2-10), consistent with James 1:17 and Romans 11:16.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 26 address the social responsibility of God's people?
options: By commanding provision for Levites, strangers, fatherless, and widows
By focusing only on personal wealth
By excluding foreigners from blessings
By requiring isolation from society
questions.correctAnswer: By commanding provision for Levites, strangers, fatherless, and widows
questions.explanation: Verses 26:12-13 emphasize social justice and communal care, aligning with Isaiah 1:17 and Matthew 25:35-40.

questions.question: What does the repeated emphasis on obedience to commandments in Deuteronomy 26 teach about the nature of covenant relationship?
options: Covenant requires wholehearted obedience and faithfulness
Covenant is unconditional regardless of behavior
Covenant depends on human merit alone
Obedience is optional for blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant requires wholehearted obedience and faithfulness
questions.explanation: Verses 26:16-19 teach that covenant is based on faithful obedience, consistent with Deuteronomy 30:16 and John 14:15.
